com.hyprmx.android.sdk
Class HyprMXButton

java.lang.Object
  android.view.View
      android.widget.ImageView
          com.hyprmx.android.sdk.HyprMXButton
All Implemented Interfaces:
android.graphics.drawable.Drawable.Callback, android.view.accessibility.AccessibilityEventSource, android.view.KeyEvent.Callback, com.hyprmx.android.sdk.utility.ImageCacheManager.OnImageLoadedListener, com.hyprmx.android.sdk.utility.OfferHolder.OnOffersAvailableResponseReceivedListener
public class HyprMXButton
extends android.widget.ImageView
implements com.hyprmx.android.sdk.utility.OfferHolder.OnOffersAvailableResponseReceivedListener, com.hyprmx.android.sdk.utility.ImageCacheManager.OnImageLoadedListener

Represents a relatively small button that can display ad content as received from the HyprMX API. Can be created using the HyprMXHelper.createButton() method or by including a HyprMXButton in an XML layout. The following example shows how to create a HyprMXButton in an XML layout. 

        <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
        <LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
                xmlns:hypr="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
                android:layout_width="fill_parent"
                android:layout_height="fill_parent"
                android:orientation="vertical" >
 
                <com.hyprmx.android.sdk.view.HyprMXButton
                        android:id="@+id/ad_button"
                        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
                        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
                        hypr:buttonSize="large" />
 
        </LinearLayout>
By extending the HyprMXActivity class and implementing the HypxMXListener methods, it's easy to receive callbacks of offer lifecycle activity. The following example shows this. 
        public class MyActivity extends HyprMXActivity {
                
                @Override
                protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
                        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
                        setContentView(R.layout.main);
                }
 
                @Override
                public void onOfferCompleted(HyprMXOffer offer) {
                        // do something on complete
                }
 
        @Override
                public void onOfferCancelled(HyprMXOffer offer) {
                        // do something on cancel
                }
 
                @Override
                public void onNoContentAvailable() {
                        // possibly do something if no content is available
                }
 
                @Override
                public void onUserOptedOut() {
                        // possibly do something if user has opted out
                }
                ...
        }
The following example shows how to create a HyprMXButton dynamically to be inserted into layouts. 
 HyprMXHelper helper = HyprMXHelper.getInstance();
 HyprMXButton button = helper.createButton(activity, HyprMXButton.ButtonSize.LARGE);
 ...
 
 viewGroup.addView(button);

Version:
$Revision: 1.0 $
Author:
bjdupuis
